realExample.title: From the audit workflow: policy upload and regulator export
realExample.competitor: During the audit the auditor uploads an insurance policy. Other audit platforms might only show "Document appears expired"—or do nothing. There is no recommendation to mark as non-compliant, and no link to which NCA or SAMA control it maps to. When the report is done, the auditor manually figures out each control and spends days copy-pasting findings into the regulator's Excel template.
realExample.arabaudit: Same upload. Our AI flags the expiry, recommends "Mark as Non-Compliant," and maps the finding to the specific control (e.g. NCA ECC 2.2 or SAMA criteria) so the auditor knows exactly what to do. When the report is ready, one click exports the .xlsx in the format the regulator requires. No manual mapping, no copy-paste.

frameworks.title: Built for the Big Three Saudi frameworks
frameworks.subtitle: NCA, SAMA, and SDAIA who makes the rules and who must comply

nca.name: NCA ECC-2024
points: Baseline security standard for the Kingdom; protects Critical National Infrastructure.
114 controls in 5 domains: Governance, Defense, Resilience, Third-Party & Cloud, and ICS.
ECC-2024 is tougher on cloud security, ransomware defense, and supply chain risk.

sama.name: SAMA CSF
points: Saudi Central Bank's Cyber Security Framework for financial sector stability.
Maturity model 0–5: Level 3 is the minimum pass; Level 5 is the gold standard.
Focus: fraud prevention, transaction security, and business continuity.
sama.for: Banks, insurance, fintechs, and financing companies.

sdaia.name: SDAIA / PDPL
points: SDAIA owns the Personal Data Protection Law (PDPL), the Saudi GDPR.
Key concept: consent. Audits require Privacy Policy, Consent Forms, and data evidence.
Focus: consent management, data subject rights, and breach notification.
sdaia.for: Everyone that collects, processes, or shares personal data.

auditProcess.title: Understanding the Saudi Audit Process
auditProcess.subtitle: Companies often follow NCA, SAMA, and PDPL. Teams manually map frameworks in Excel, we turn that into one workflow.

dualCompliance.headline: The dual framework challenge
dualCompliance.description: A Saudi bank is financial entity, critical infrastructure, and a handler of personal data—so it must comply with NCA, SAMA, and PDPL. Today that means doing everything two or three times.
dualCompliance.example: One password policy → written for SAMA, rewritten for NCA → audited twice → submitted to two portals

steps: Scoping: Which of 114 controls apply to your organization
Gap analysis: Compare current security posture vs. ECC-2024
Policy prep: Align policies with the five domains (Governance, Defense, Resilience, Third-Party & Cloud, ICS)
Evidence collection: Screenshots, logs, training records
Internal audit: Dry run before the official NCA audit
Submit to NCA Portal: Final compliance report in the required format
workflows.pain: Manual Excel mapping of evidence to 114 controls—days of copy-paste into the government template

steps: Determine target maturity: Usually Level 3 minimum (Level 5 is the gold standard)
Maturity enhancement: Build and document processes; SAMA cares how well they work over time
Continuous monitoring: Track KRIs and KPIs
Periodic reporting: Submit maturity status to the Central Bank
Follow-up: Address SAMA feedback and close gaps
workflows.pain: Proving maturity over time—not just one-time compliance

harmonization.title: ArabAudit's framework harmonization

One unified policy: Write once for both NCA and SAMA
Collect once: Upload evidence (e.g. MFA report) and tag for SAMA and NCA
Export twice: One-click export to NCA and SAMA portals in their required formats
